review.title: Towards reducing the multidimensionality of OLAP cubes using the Evolutionary Algorithms and Factor Analysis Methods
review.abstract: Data Warehouses are structures with large amount of data collected from heterogeneous sources to be used in a decision support system. Data Warehouses analysis identifies hidden patterns initially unexpected which analysis requires great memory and computation cost. Data reduction methods were proposed to make this analysis easier. In this paper, we present a hybrid approach based on Genetic Algorithms (GA) as Evolutionary Algorithms and the Multiple Correspondence Analysis (MCA) as Analysis Factor Methods to conduct this reduction. Our approach identifies reduced subset of dimensions from the initial subset p where p'<p where it is proposed to find the profile fact that is the closest to reference. GAs identify the possible subsets and the Khi formula of the ACM evaluates the quality of each subset. The study is based on a distance measurement between the reference and n facts profile extracted from the Warehouses.

metadata.title: Towards reducing the multidimensionality of OLAP cubes using the Evolutionary Algorithms and Factor Analysis Methods

sections.text: Data warehouses are structures with large amounts of data from heterogeneous sources that can be used in a decision support system. Data warehouses analyses initially identify unexpected hidden patterns that require large storage and computational costs to analyze. Data reduction methods have been proposed to simplify this analysis. In this paper, we present a hybrid approach based on Genetic Algorithms (GA) as Evolutionary Algorithms and Multiple Correspondence Analysis (MCA) as Analytical Factor Methods to perform this reduction. Our approach identifies a reduced subset of dimensions p'versus the original subset p, which proposes p' < p where the profile fact closest to the reference should be found. GAs identify the possible subsets and the Khi ² formula of the ACM evaluates the quality of each subset. The study is based on distance measurement between the reference and n factor profile, the AP extracts the response algorithm from the Data Warehouse.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction.
sections.text: Data warehouses (DW) are used to collect and store large amounts of data in large tables, which are then processed, helping to extract knowledge and help in decision-making. DW collects the data stored from heterogeneous sources and creates centralized huge databases, initially identifying hidden patterns that have been treated once. In (W. INMON, 1994), the authors present these large data structures and their architecture as the result of data collection from centralized, initially decentralized databases, which they can homogenize and provide the ability to handle multidimensional data structures called OLAP cubes. (L.Lebart, A.Morineau, M.Piron, 2006) consider multidimensional statics as an interesting analytical axis that should be investigated. Random compilation of data and its arrangement in the DW may contain unnecessary and superfluous data that have no real interest for the analyst and even provide erroneous results when included in processing.

sections.heading: 2. Related Works and Motivations
sections.text: This year is the highest in the history of the country.

sections.heading: 4. Proposed Approach for Data Warehouse Reduction.
sections.text: In our approach, we propose a method for reducing the number of dimensions p 2. 2. with the AGs and the MCA. We try to identify a subset p 'of the dimensions in which p' < p, in which we can find the next elements for reference. Each individual returned by the GA represents a subset of dimensions and is considered a possible solution. Each solution is represented by a chromosome that contains as many genes as the DW dimensions. Each gene has two possible values: 1 if we hold the corresponding dimension in the solution and 0 otherwise. We then calculate for each solution the distance between the individual facts contained in the extracted sample and each fact. We then consider the minimum value of the distances we choose when calculating the sum of all d-positions that we would not be able to identify the facts with minimum values and that are close to the reference. The approach is based on the similarity between two individuals profile.

sections.heading: 5. Application on an Example.
sections.text: This year, the European Central Bank (ECB) has pumped more than one billion euros into public budgets in the first three months of its existence.
